importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Diwali is celebrated on this date, marking the start of the autumn festival season for over a billion South Asian people, promoting cultural unity and interfaith harmony globally.

Sikhs commemorate Bandi Chhor Divas on this date, marking the liberation of Guru Hargobind and 52 Hindu kings from imprisonment, highlighting historical resistance to oppression and religious freedom.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: Diwali is celebrated annually between October and November, making it a recurring global cultural event that brings communities together across borders and faiths.

keyTakeAways: Diwali, also known as Deepavali, is a major cultural and religious festival observed by Hindus, Sikhs, Jains, and Buddhists worldwide.
The festival symbolizes the triumph of light over darkness, good over evil, and justice over oppression.
The holiday spans five days with distinct observances: Dhanteras, Choti Diwali, Diwali (Lakshmi Puja), Padwa, and Bhai Dooj, each with unique traditions and spiritual meanings.
For Sikhs, Diwali is celebrated as Bandi Chhor Divas, commemorating the release of Guru Hargobind and 52 Hindu kings from imprisonment, a significant event in religious and human rights history.
For Jains, Diwali marks the attainment of enlightenment by Lord Mahavira; for Buddhists, it commemorates Emperor Ashoka’s adoption of Buddhism.
The festival transcends religion and is now widely celebrated by people of all faiths and backgrounds, promoting cultural exchange and community bonding.
Diwali is tied to economic renewal, as many businesses open new accounts during the festival, reflecting its role in cultural and economic life.
Traditional customs include lighting diyas (oil lamps), decorating homes with rangolis, setting off fireworks, and sharing sweets and gifts with family and neighbors.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Diwali, a major festival of light and renewal, is celebrated by over a billion Hindus, Sikhs, Jains, and Buddhists globally on October 20, 2025. Rooted in ancient myths such as the triumph of Rama over Ravana and Lord Krishna defeating Narakasura, Diwali symbolizes the victory of light over darkness, good over evil, and justice over oppression. The festival spans five days, each with unique traditions: Dhanteras marks the beginning with purchases of wealth-related items; Choti Diwali celebrates Krishna’s victory; Diwali (Lakshmi Puja) is the main day of feasting and worship; Padwa honors marital love and Krishna’s protection of villagers; and Bhai Dooj celebrates sibling bonds. For Sikhs, Diwali is observed as Bandi Chhor Divas, commemorating the liberation of Guru Hargobind and 52 kings from imprisonment, highlighting historical resistance and human rights. For Jains and Buddhists, Diwali marks spiritual enlightenment (Lord Mahavira) and the conversion of Emperor Ashoka, respectively. The festival transcends religion, becoming a global cultural event emphasizing community, renewal, and shared values.
title: It’s Diwali, a time for light, community and fresh starts
